facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1111 of 1965 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1111 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 11, 1963 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 36-D of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated April 11, 1963 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 36-D of 1963.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal summarily dismissed the appeal from Second Appeal upholding decree in favour of respondent by Additional District Judge, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: ment and order dated April 11, 1963 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench at Delhi  in a Letters Patent Appeal which summarily dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant from a judgment and order in a Second Appeal upholding the decree in favour of the respondent passed by the Additional District Judge, Delhi.

facts.text: Respondent appointed Sub-Inspector of Police by Inspector-General of Police in Sind before partition of India.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had been appointed a Sub-Inspector of Police by the Inspector-General of Police in Sind before the partition of India and was thereafter posted in Delhi by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police Delhi after his migration to India.

facts.text: Respondent posted in Delhi by Deputy Inspector-General after migration to India.

anchor.surface_text: and was thereafter posted in Delhi by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police Delhi after his migration to India.

facts.text: In 1949, respondent posted as Sub-Inspector of Police in Police Station Daryaganj, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1949 he was posted as Sub Inspector of Police in Police Station Daryaganj, Delhi.

facts.text: Departmental enquiry launched against respondent in 1949 on charge of acceptance of bribe in connection with a criminal case.

anchor.surface_text: A departmental enquiry was launched against him on the charge of acceptance of bribe in companynection with a criminal case in the same year.

facts.text: Diwanchand Dhatia employed as Deputy Superintendent of Police in City of Delhi up to April 1949, retired that month, re-employed as DSP Enforcement Department.

anchor.surface_text: The officer entrusted with the enquiry was one Diwanchand Dhatia who was employed up to April 1949 as a Deputy Supe- rintendent of Police in the City of Delhi. He retired from service in that month but was re-employed from the date of retirement as a Deputy Superintendent of Police  Enforcement Department .

facts.text: Enquiry against respondent took place after Diwanchand's retirement but during his re-employment.

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry against the respondent had taken place after the retirement of the said Diwanchand but during the -period of his reemployment.

facts.text: Respondent found guilty and dismissed from service by order dated December 8, 1949 passed by Jagannath, Superintendent of Police in Delhi Police Force.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was found guilty of the charge and was dismissed from service by the order dated December 8, 1949 , passed by one Jagannath, a Superintendent of Police in the Delhi Police Force.

facts.text: Appellant (Union of India) filed suit challenging dismissal on January 12, 1954 in court of Subordinate Judge Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a suit challenging his dismissal on the grounds already mentioned in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge Delhi on January 12, 1954.

facts.text: Defendant Union of India filed written statement disputing contentions of plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant-Union of India filed its written statement disputing the companytentions of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed suit in favour of plaintiff on issues of competency of Jagannath and Diwanchand Bhatia.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge framed several issues -the principal ones relate to the companypetency of Jagannath to pass the order of dismissal and of Diwanchand Bhatia to companyduct the enquiry against the plaintiff. Finding in favour of the plaintiff on both the issues, he decreed the suit.

facts.text: Decree upheld by Additional District Judge, Delhi in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: This decree was upheld in appeal by the Additional District Judge, Delhi and in Second Appeal by a single Judge of the Punjab High Court

facts.text: Single Judge of Punjab High Court upheld in Second Appeal, modified salary figure.

anchor.surface_text: and in Second Appeal by a single Judge of the Punjab High Court who modified the decree by an alteration in the figure of the salary claimed by the plaintiff but upholding his claim on the main issues.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal dismissed summarily.

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent Appeal, as already stated, was dismissed summarily.

facts.text: Jagannath was functioning as Superintendent of Police but not designated as District Superintendent of Police.

anchor.surface_text: The first companytention on behalf of the appellant was that Jagannath who was functioning as a Superintendent of Police but number designated as a District Superintendent of Police

facts.text: Diwanchand Bhatia received charge as Officiating DSP Enforcement on forenoon of 28th April 1949 (Ex. D-5).

anchor.surface_text: Ex. D-5 is a certificate to the effect that Diwanchand Bhatia had on the forenoon of 28th April 1949 received charge of the office of the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Enforcement, Delhi with the designation Officiating Deputy Superintendent of Police.

facts.text: Order of IG Police Delhi dated June 6, 1949 posted Diwanchand Bhatia to city (Ex. D-4).

anchor.surface_text: Ex. D-4, the order of the Inspector-General of Police, Delhi dated June 6, 1949 shows that Diwanchand Bhatia was posted to city vice Malik Bodh Raj, Deputy Supe- rintendent of Police, who will take over charge as Deputy Superintendent of Police, Enforcement.

facts.text: Diwanchand Bhatia conducted the enquiry against respondent.

anchor.surface_text: There is also the oral testimony of Diwanchand Bhatia to the effect that he had taken over charge as shown in those documents and that he had companyducted the enquiry against the respondent.

facts.text: Diwanchand Bhatia received application from Jagannath for enquiry, did preliminary enquiry, sent to DM for approval, DM directed departmental enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Diwanchand Bhatia stated in his evidence in chief that he had received an application for making an enquiry against the plaintiff from Jagannath, Superintendent of Police -and that after making a preliminary enquiry when he found a prima facie case against the plaintiff he sent the same to the District Magistrate for approval.

facts.text: File relating to departmental enquiry destroyed under Police Rule 12.35 on 15th January 1953 by order of Abdul Rehman.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Rehman, the Superintendent of Police, C.I.D. who gave evidence in this case stated that the file relating to the departmental enquiry against the plaintiff had been destroyed under Police Rule 12.35 by his order. He also referred to the document Ex. D-2 which is an extract regarding the destruction of Fauji Missals. The order seems to have been passed on 15th January 1953

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside judgments below, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the judgment and order of the companyrts below set aside and the suit filed by the respondent dismissed.

facts.text: Jagannath was Superintendent of Police, City, Delhi with jurisdiction over PS Faiz Bazar where plaintiff posted.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Jagannath was the Superintendent of Police, City and all the police stations of the city were under his charge. ... with jurisdiction over the police station Faiz Bazar where the plaintiff was posted

facts.text: In 1950, two Superintendents of Police in Delhi: one for Delhi City, one for New Delhi; District Magistrate in charge of entire Delhi area.

anchor.surface_text: He said that he was posted as Superintendent of Police at the headquarters at Delhi in 1950. According to him, the District Magistrate was in charge of the entire Delhi area including New Delhi, Old Delhi and rural areas. Further, the police officer in charge of the entire area was the Inspector-General of Police and there were two Superintendents of Police, one for Delhi City and the other for New Delhi.

issues.text: whether the dismissal of the respondent from service in the police force was illegal on the ground that the officer entrusted with the departmental enquiry against the respondent was not a police officer

anchor.surface_text: The questions canvassed in this appeal were whether the dismissal of the respondent from service in the police force was illegal on the ground that the officer entrusted with the departmental enquiry against the respondent was not a police officer

issues.text: whether the order of dismissal passed by Shri Jagannath was invalid because he was not a District Superintendent of Police

anchor.surface_text: secondly, whether the order of dismissal passed by Shri Jagannath was invalid because he was not a District Superinendent of Police and thirdly, whether the dismissal

issues.text: whether the dismissal was void on account of non-compliance with the provisions of Rule 16.38 of the Punjab Police Rules

anchor.surface_text: of Police and thirdly, whether the dismissal was void on account of non-compliance with the provisions of Rule 16.38 of the Punjab Police Rules. In order to appreciate the points

arguments.claim: Jagannath who was functioning as a Superintendent of Police but not designated as a District Superintendent of Police was quite competent to pass the order of dismissal against the respondent

anchor.surface_text: The first contention on behalf of the appellant was that Jagannath who was functioning as a Superintendent of Police but not designated as a District Superintendent of Police was quite competent to pass the order of dismissal against the respondent. Under s. 4 of the Police Act V of 1861,

arguments.claim: The officer conducting the enquiry must be superior in status to the person against whom charges had been levelled and Deputy Superintendent of Police was superior to Sub Inspector; Diwanchand Bhatia was a police officer

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was contended before us that all that this rule requires was that the officer conducting the enquiry must be superior in status to the person against whom charges had been levelled and there can be no doubt that Deputy Superintendent of Police was an officer superior to a Sub Inspector of Police.

anchor.surface_text: It was sought to be argued before us by counsel for the respondent that Diwanchand Bhatia, when he conducted the enquiry had already retired from the post of police officer and he was only re-employed in the Enforcement Department and this would not make him a police officer.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Anthony who argued on behalf of the respondent drew our attention to a judgment of this Court in The State of Uttar Pradesh and others v. Babu Ram where it was observed that the Police Act and the Rules made thereunder constituted a selfcontained Code

arguments.claim: Words 'Superintendent of Police' in Rules and 'District Superintendent of Police' in Act refer to one and the same authority; no distinction

anchor.surface_text: The question therefore arises whether the words Superintendent of Police in the Rules and the words District Superintendent of Police in the Act refer to one and the same authority, or whether there is any distinction or difference between the two. In our opinion, there is none.

arguments.claim: Administration of police in district vested in District SP but possible multiple SPs per district due to expansion; Jagannath had jurisdiction over relevant PS

anchor.surface_text: This finds support from the testimony of Abdul Rehman... Shri Jagannath was the Superintendent of Police, City and all the police stations of the city were under his charge... with jurisdiction over the police station Faiz Bazar where the plaintiff was posted

arguments.claim: Diwanchand Bhatia was a police officer as per Ex. D-5 (charge on 28 Apr 1949 as Officiating DSP Enforcement), Ex. D-4 (posted 6 Jun 1949), and his testimony

arguments.claim: Testimony of Diwanchand Bhatia shows compliance with Rule 16.38: received application from Jagannath, preliminary enquiry, sent to DM, DM directed departmental enquiry

anchor.surface_text: Diwanchand Bhatia stated in his evidence in chief that he had received an application for making an enquiry against the plaintiff from Jagannath, Superintendent of Police -and that after making a preliminary enquiry when he found a prima facie case against the plaintiff he sent the same to the District Magistrate for approval.

arguments.claim: No reason to disbelieve Diwanchand Bhatia's testimony on Rule 16.38 compliance; file destroyed lawfully under Rule 12.35 on 15 Jan 1953 by Abdul Rehman (Ex D-2)

anchor.surface_text: We see no reason to disbelieve the testimony of Diwanchand Bhatia. The learned trial Judge did not frame an issue on this point and Abdul Rehman... stated that the file relating to the departmental enquiry against the plaintiff had been destroyed under Police Rule 12.35 by his order... on 15th January 1953

arguments.claim: Provisions of Rule 16.38 even if directory require substantial compliance, which was present

anchor.surface_text: There what was said was It is not necessary to decide whether the provisions of Rule 16.38 of the Punjab Police Rules are mandatory or directory. Even assuming that the rule is directory, we find that there has been no substantial compliance with its provisions.

arguments.claim: Competency of Jagannath and Diwanchand Bhatia to conduct enquiry and pass dismissal order

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge framed several issues -the principal ones relate to the competency of Jagannath to pass the order of dismissal and of Diwanchand Bhatia to conduct the enquiry against the plaintiff. Finding in favour of the plaintiff on both the issues, he decreed the suit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: uilty of the charge and was dismissed from service by the order dated December 8, 1949 , passed by one Jagannath, a Superintendent of Police in the De

arguments.court_reasoning: Reversed on appeal; Act, Rules, evidence show competence

holdings.text: Jagannath, functioning as Superintendent of Police, City, Delhi with jurisdiction over the relevant police station, was competent to pass the order of dismissal as 'Superintendent of Police' in the Rules equates to 'District Superintendent of Police' in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is thus no incongruity between the Act and the Rules which have to be read together and as Jagannath, Superintendent of Police, was undoubtedly the Superintendent of Police, City of Delhi with jurisdiction over the police station Faiz Bazar where the plaintiff was posted, he was competent to pass the order of dismissal on him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Police Act sections 1, 3, 4, 7 and Punjab Police Rules 11-13, 16.1; supported by testimony of Abdul Rehman confirming multiple SPs possible in district and Jagannath's charge over city PS.

holdings.text: Diwanchand Bhatia was a police officer and competent to conduct the departmental enquiry against the Sub-Inspector respondent under Rule 16.24 as an Officiating Deputy Superintendent of Police superior in rank.

anchor.surface_text: It was sought to be argued before us by counsel for the respondent that Diwanchand Bhatia, when he conducted the enquiry had already retired from the post of police officer and he was only re-employed in the Enforcement Department and this would not make him a police officer. We see no force in this contention as the Enforcement Department was still a police department and a Deputy Superintendent of Police Enforcement was still a Deputy Superintendent of Police.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence from Ex. D-4, Ex. D-5 and Diwanchand's testimony confirm appointment as Officiating DSP Enforcement post-retirement, exchange with another DSP, Enforcement as police department; superior rank to SI per rules.

holdings.text: There was compliance with Rule 16.38 of Punjab Police Rules; dismissal not void for non-compliance.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we see no reason not to accept the evidence of Diwanchand Bhatia according to which R.16.38 of Chapter XVI had been complied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Diwanchand's credible testimony of preliminary enquiry, report to DM who approved departmental enquiry; no issue framed below; file lawfully destroyed under Rule 12.35 (Ex. D-2); distinguishes Babu Ram on facts as substantial compliance present even if directory.

holdings.text: Dismissal order valid; suit challenging dismissal dismissed; lower court judgments set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the judgment and order of the courts below set aside and the suit filed by the respondent dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All three grounds challenging dismissal rejected; procedures under Police Act and Rules followed.

precedents.citation: The State of Uttar Pradesh and others v. Babu Ram 1

anchor.surface_text: The State of Uttar Pradesh and others v. Babu Ram 1 where it was observed that the Police Act and the Rules made thereunder companystituted a selfcontained Code providing for the appointment of police officers and prescribing the procedure for their removal.

precedents.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Babu Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: Police Act and Rules constitute a self-contained code for appointment and removal of police officers; no departure from rules possible; strict compliance mandatory to justify dismissal
precedents.cited_holding: the Police Act and the Rules made thereunder constituted a selfcontained Code providing for the appointment of police officers and prescribing the procedure for their removal

anchor.surface_text: Delhi Administration v. Chanan Shah 2 There what was said was It is number necessary to decide whether the provisions of Rule 16.38 of the Punjab Police Rules are mandatory or directory. Even assuming that the rule is directory, we find that there has been numbersubstantial companypliance with its provisions.

precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions of Rule 16.38 mandatory or directory; even if directory, substantial compliance required
precedents.cited_holding: It is not necessary to decide whether the provisions of Rule 16.38 of the Punjab Police Rules are mandatory or directory. Even assuming that the rule is directory, we find that there has been no substantial compliance with its provisions.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and order of courts below set aside; suit of respondent dismissed.
directions: No order as to costs of this appeal
Previous order for costs not disturbed

anchor.surface_text: It was sought to be argued before us by counsel for the respondent that Diwanchand Bhatia, when he conducted the enquiry had already retired from the post of police officer and he was only re-employed in the Enforcement Department and this would not make him a police officer. We see no force in this contention as the Enforcement Department was still a police department and a Deputy Superintendent of Police Enforcement was still a Deputy Superintendent of Police.
